tit.e: Jikku Kannongyo (one of the Buddhist scriptures)

sen.j: 『十句観音経』（じっくかんのんぎょう）は、仏教経典の一。
sen.e: "Jikku Kannongyo" is one of Buddhist scriptures.

sen.e: It is also called "Enmei Jikku Kannongyo" ("Kannon Sutra for Long Life in Ten Statements"); the person who added the two words "en mei" is Hakuin, who lived during the Edo period and is considered as the founder of chuko no so (father of restoration) of Rinzai sect (as described below).

sen.j: 『十句観音経』に関する最古の文献は、中国天台宗の祖師列伝を記録した南宋咸淳四明東湖沙門志磐撰『仏祖統紀』（1269年）で、そこには次のような南北朝時代の記録が載せられている。
sen.e: The oldest literature relating to "Jikku Kannongyo" is "Bussotoki" (1269) which was compiled in 1269 by shamon (priest) named Chi-p'an (Shiban) in Nantoko in Southern Sung Dynasty and which is a record on the lives of the founders of Chinese Tendai sect; the literature contains the following record of the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.e: In Song (Southern Dynasty) in 450, Liu Yilong, the third-generation Emperor Wen, waged war on Northern Wei Dynasty over oppositions by Liu Kangzu, Shen Qingzhi, and others.

sen.j: 柳元景・薛安都・龐法起らの本軍は連戦連勝して潼関を陥れたが、一方、淮北に別軍を進めた王玄謨（おうげんぼ）は、碻磝を陥れ、滑台を包囲したにもかかわらず、北魏の太武帝の親征軍が大挙して渡河したため敗走に追い込まれた。
sen.e: The main army consisting of Liu Yuanjing, Xne Andu, 龐法起, etc. made a series of victories and took Tong Gate; on the other hand, Wang Xuanmo, who proceeded his army in Huaibei, took Qiao'ao (a geographical name) and seized Huatai (a geographical name) but was forced to take flight in the face of the imperial expeditionary force led by Taiwudi of Northern Wei Dynasty fording in great number.

sen.j: この話は450年の事跡ということであるが、他に記載する古資料がないため信憑性は乏しく、『仏祖統紀』撰述の時代に『十句観音経』が普及していたということを示唆するのみである。
sen.e: Although the above story is said to have taken place in 450, since there are no other ancient documents mentioning the same, it can only be suggested that "Jikku Kannongyo" was popular during the period in which "Bussotoki" was compiled.

sen.j: このほかに、北魏の孫敬徳が処刑されそうになったときに、同一の経文を唱えたところ、死刑執行人が刀を振り下ろしても刀が折れてしまうという霊験があったという伝説もあるが、孫が唱えたのは別の『高王観音経』であるともいい、はっきりしない。
sen.e: In addition to the above, there is also a legend describing the miracle according to which, when Sonkeitoku of Northern Wei Dynasty was about to be executed and the executioner brought the axe down, Sonkeitoku uttered the same scripture and the axe was broken; however, another legend has it that the scripture uttered by Sonkeitoku was some other "Kookannonkyo" (one of Buddhist scriptures), thus the story is not certain.

sen.j: 日本では、霊元天皇が最も霊験あらたかな経典を霊空和尚に探させた結果、これに行き着いたという伝説がある。
sen.e: In Japan, there is a legend that when Emperor Reigen had a high priest named Reiku search for the scripture having the most remarkably miraculous effect, Reiku selected Jikku Kannongyo.

sen.e: However, there is no evidence to support this legend other than that it was mentioned by Hakuin in "Enmei Jikku Kannongyo Reigenki" ("The Wondrous Power of the Kannon Sutra for Long Life in Ten Statements").

sen.j: 白隠は上記の他いくつかの伝説を採り上げ、偽経といえどもこれだけ霊験があるのだからと、人々に唱えることを推奨し、『延命十句観音経霊験記』をあらわしたため普及した。

sen.j: また、本来の「観音経（妙法蓮華経観世音菩薩普門品第二十五）」は、短い偈文（世尊偈）部分のみでも500字を越える長大な経典であり日常の読経としては長すぎるため、代用として十句観音経を読むことも行われており、鎌田茂雄などの禅僧がそれを薦めている。
sen.e: Also, the original Kannon-gyo Sutra (Myohorengekyo Kanzeon Bosatsu Fumombon, Chapter 25) is quite long, in which even only the short part of the gebun (or sesonge; recitation of verses) exceeds 500 words; accordingly, sometimes Jikku Kannongyo is read as a replacement, as was recommended by Zen monks such as Shigeo KAMATA.
